_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Introduction:
At the beginning of the 1900s water-borne diseases were a leading cause of death in the United States (U.S.).  Epidemics of typhoid, cholera, dysentery and other water-borne diseases occurred.  After chlorine's introduction into public water supplies, deaths from typhoid in the U.S.  dropped dramatically from 25,000 in 1900 to less than 20 in 1960.  Water-borne disease is even still a leading cause of infant mortality in many countries throughout Asia, Africa, and Latin America where infant mortality rates are 10 to 20 times greater than in the U.S.  In the U.S., however, water-borne disease has been virtually eliminated due to an effective public health strategy of utilizing chlorine for drinking water disinfection.  Chlorine disinfection is arguably one of the greatest achievements for public health worldwide in the last hundred years and is credited with increasing the life expectancy of Americans by more than 50 percent.

The use of chlorine is not risk free, however.  Historically it is clear that utilities have recognized the risks and have been successful in developing procedures to handle chlorine safely and to protect the off-site public and the environment from potential accidental releases.

As an added layer of protection, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) promulgated the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule in volume 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) part 68.  The goal of these regulations is to reduce the risk to employees, the public, and the environment by preventing the accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  The Miami-Dade Water and Sewer Department (MDWASD) John E. Preston Water Treatment Plant (WTP) is regulated because it stores chlorine above the threshold quantity defined in these regulations.

The RMP Program Level 3 regulations are similar to the requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management Program (PSMP) rule in volume 29 CFR part 1910.119.

Although Florida public sector employees  are not covered by federal OSHA regulations, Miami-Dade County Administrative Order 7-14 requires compliance with OSHA regulations. 

The John E. Preston WTP has always understood the risks associated with chlorine and has maintained a well-trained staff and a safely operated and maintained facility.  The John E. Preston WTP's track record is exemplary with respect to handling hazardous chemicals.  Furthermore, the John E. Preston WTP has taken a comprehensive approach to be in full compliance with the RMP and PSMP regulations.

The key element of complying with the RMP and PSMP rules is development of policies, operating procedures, maintenance programs, and emergency response plans to ensure the safety of employees and the public.  MDWASD is committed to providing a safe and healthy work environment to its employees and protecting the public, on-site and off-site property, and the environment from releases of chlorine.  Hence, MDWASD has prepared a comprehensive Program Level 3 RMP.  This Executive Summary briefly describes the following key elements of the John E. Preston RMP:

¿-	Accidental release prevention and emergency response polices
¿-	General facility and regulated substance information
¿-	Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific  preventive steps
¿-	Five-year accident history summary
¿-	Emergency response program summary
¿-	Planned changes to improve safety

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
MDWASD's accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven chlorine process technology and safety systems, incorporates staff training, provides detailed information on the hazards of chlorine and process safety management, implements operational and maintenance standard operating procedures, trains and plans for emergency response and emergency actions, includes contractor safety, and uses tested and proven m

anagement system practices.

General Facility and Regulated Substance Information:
MDWASD owns and operates the John E. Preston WTP.  The facility's mission is to protect public health by providing safe drinking water.  The John E. Preston WTP is located at 1100 West 2nd Avenue, Hialeah, Florida.  The plant is bounded by West 2nd Avenue to the east, West 13th Street to the north, West 9th Street to the south, and by West 3rd Avenue to the west.  The John E. Preston WTP covers 17.3 acres.  

The John E. Preston WTP stores chlorine which is a regulated toxic substance under RMP rule. The chlorine system at the John E. Preston WTP provides chlorine to the softened water to maintain required disinfection levels for drinking water.  The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the John E. Preston WTP at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantity in the RMP rule.  

Chlorine is delivered by the Florida East Coast Railway in 90-ton rail cars.  The rail cars are delivered to the John. E. Preston WTP via a spur to the chlorine car enclosure.  The rail cars contain liquid chlorine under pressure. The liquid chlorine flows from the rail cars through the chlorine pipeline to the evaporators located in the Chlorine Room.  At the evaporators, the liquid chlorine is heated and converted into chlorine gas.  The evaporators are equipped with high and low temperature alarms to ensure that normal temperature is maintained.  Chlorine gas then flows from the evaporators through the temperature-actuated control valve to the chlorinators. The chlorinators control the feed rate of the chlorine gas to the process.  Injection of the chlorine into the process water produces hypochlorous acid that flows through polyvinyl chloride piping to the various injection points in the treatment process.

The John E. Preston WTP chlorine system is provided with a number of safety features to protect the employees and the surrounding community.  Safety features include emergency shut-off

valves, chlorine leak detectors, audio and visual alarm system, isolation valves, high and low temperature alarms, high and low pressure alarms, pressure regulators, expansion tanks, rupture disks, and pressure relief valves.  Furthermore, Chlorine "C" Kits and personal protective equipment, including self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), are available in the event of a chlorine release.  

Emergency shut-off valves are located as follows:
¿-	At rail car valve
¿-	Immediately after the monel transfer hose or "whip"
¿-	On both pipes entering the Chlorine Room

The emergency shut-off valves are activated by actuating a pull button at an emergency shutdown valve panel.  The emergency shutdown valve panels are located at the: 1)  chlorine car enclosure; 2) outside the chlorine room and 3) near filter No. 3 backwash control station.  Additional manually-operated isolation valves are located throughout the chlorine system.

The leak detection and alarm systems are located at the following locations:
¿-	Chlorine car enclosure 
¿-	Chlorine Room

The leak detection system activates audio and visual alarms when a chlorine concentration of 0.5 parts per million (ppm) or higher is detected.  When the chlorine alarms are engaged, personnel are restricted from entering the chlorine area without the appropriate personnel protective equipment.  

A perimeter fence and locked gates surround the John E. Preston WTP.  Security cameras are located throughout the plant and are monitored off-site.  Security guards at plant entrances ensure access control.  Employees are on-site 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
The John E. Preston WTP accidental release prevention program includes the following key elements:
¿-	Detailed management system.
¿-	Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
¿-	Comprehe

nsive preventive maintenance program.
¿-	Performance of process hazard analysis (PHA) of chlorine system, with operation and maintenance staff participation and review, and trained PHA facilitator.
¿-	Chlorine system standard operating procedures (SOPs), written by the operations staff.  
¿-	Training of plant operators in chlorine system SOPs.
¿-	Training of maintenance staff in chlorine system maintenance program.
¿-	Implementation of an incident investigation program.
¿-	Availability of personal protective equipment, including SCBA.
¿-	Training of WTP staff relative to awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, presence of chlorine detectors and alarms, and remotely controlled shut-off devices on the chlorine storage tanks.
¿-	Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and safety data sheets (SDSs), along with process and chemical safety information.
¿-	Specifications for the chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference.  Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the John E. Preston WTP.

Process Hazard Analysis:
In 1997 a detailed PHA was conducted of the chlorine system process, including safety features, procedures, and maintenance.  The PHA was updated in 2001, 2004, 2009, 2014, and 2019.  Recommendation resulting from the 2019 PHA are in the process of being evaluated and/or implemented.

Incident Investigation:
The John E. Preston WTP investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in injury to personnel, injury to the public, damage to the environment, or property damage so that similar accidents can be prev

ented.  An investigation team will be assembled, and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are evaluated, and appropriate recommendations are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and used as needed to revise operation and maintenance procedures.

Standard Operating Procedures:
The John E. Preston WTP has prepared written SOPs for the chlorine system.  Written SOPs include: startup, normal operation, emergency shutdown, startup after emergency shutdown, chlorine rail car receipt, chlorine rail car connection and chlorine rail car disconnection, and transferring chlorine rail car from standby to in-service.  The SOPs are annual reviewed by the Chief Treatment Plant Operator to confirm that they are current and accurate.

Mechanical Integrity and Management-of-Change:
The John E. Preston WTP has a comprehensive mechanical integrity program that utilizes Electronic Asset Management System (EAMS) software.  The chlorine system receives regular preventive maintenance based on the manufacturer's recommendation.  Additionally, the John E. Preston WTP has a management-of-change policy to ensure that all changes to the chlorine system are properly documented.  Employees involved in operating and maintaining the chlorine process whose job tasks will be affected by the change shall be informed of, and trained in, the change prior to start-up.

Pre-Startup Review:
The John E. Preston WTP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting up a new covered process or after a shutdown event, or prior to starting up modifications to the chlorination processes that require implementation of the management-of-change procedure.

Training:
John E. Preston WTP employees presently involved in operating and maintaining the chlorine system are trained in the chlorine process and the applicable

operation and maintenance procedures.  MDWASD ensures that each employee newly assigned to the chlorine process is trained and tested to be competent in the process safety management, SOPs, consequences of deviation from the SOPs, and chlorine process safety features.  All employees involved in operating and maintaining the chlorine system have been trained in the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities.  

Management Personnel are trained on Process Safety Management and compliance with Federal and State Regulations pertaining to Risk Management Planning and Process Safety Management.  All on-site facility personnel that are not involved directly with the chlorine system are also trained in Process Safety Management, Emergency Evacuation, and the MDWASD Emergency Action Plan.

Process Safety Management refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process, Management Personnel, and employees assigned to the facility to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  MDWASD retains records of initial and refresher training, and provides certification of the records, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person(s) administering the training.

Contractors:
The John E. Preston WTP has procedures and policies in place that specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanisms to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  The John E. Preston WTP is required to provide information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes and to obtain and evaluate information regarding the contractor's safety program.

Internal Compliance Audits:
Internal compliance audits will be co

nducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  MDWASD will assemble an audit team that will include personnel knowledgeable in the RMP rule and in the chlorine process.  This team will evaluate whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the RMP rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit will be documented, recommendations evaluated, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program will be implemented.

Third-Party Audits:
MDWASD has developed procedures to engage a third-party to conduct third-party audits when required by the RMP rule.

Hot Work Permit:
The John E. Preston WTP requires that employees and contractors employ safe work practices when performing hot work in, on, or around the covered process.  The John E. Preston WTP uses a permitting program to ensure that hot work is conducted safely on, or near a process involving chlorine.

Five-Year Accident History Summary:
No reportable releases/accidents have occurred at the John E. Preston WTP during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program Summary:
MDWASD has a comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (ERP) specifically-tailored to each facility that complies with 40 CFR 68 subpart E.  The following paragraphs summarize key elements of the MDWASD ERP.

Employees working with the chlorine process are Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) technician level trained.  The HAZWOPER-trained staff will respond to chlorine leaks.  Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external resources such as the Miami-Dade County Hazardous Material Team may be solicited to aid in handling a chlorine leak.  

The ERP has been coordinated with local response agencies (Fire Department, Miami-Dade Office of Emergency Management).  The main elements of the MDWASD's ERP are: (1) chlorine release response flow chart, res

ponsibilities of various personnel at the facility, duties of on-scene incident commander, site response team, and site safety representative; (2) details of emergency recognition and prevention at the facility; (3) procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations; and (4) training of WTP staff relative to implementation of the ERP.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
A PHA of the chlorine system was conducted on May 23, 2019.  The PHA identified certain recommendations to improve safety.  MDWASD is currently evaluating the recommendations resulting from the May 23, 2019 PHA.  The key planned safety improvement at the John E. Preston WTP is to replace the elemental chlorine with sodium hypochlorite (bleach).  It is roughly estimated that construction of the proposed sodium hypochlorite facility will be completed in late 2021.
